junit@yahoogroups.com wrote:

>> I'd actually prefer to decouple the four steps in a way that
>> recreating the state one of those steps needs isn't too hard.
>> 
>> Each of those steps already sounds complex enough to test on
>> its own. We will probably want to have more than one test for
>> each, which will likely lead to a "combinatorical explosion"
>> if we test all the four steps together.
> 
> The combinatorial explosion appears if you don't maintain
> state.  With this approach, your tests are going to look like:
> 
> Test1:
> 	1
> Test2:
> 	1-2
> Test3:
> 	1-2-3
> Test4:
> 	1-2-3-4
> 
> This is a huge waste of time.

I agree that the above would be a waste of time. It seems to me as if you
didn't consider the decoupling I referred to above, though.

The approach I'd prefer would more look like

Test1:
	1
Test2:
	1m-2
Test3:
	2m-3
Test4:
	3m-4

where the Xm steps are mock steps which are presumly (with a well testable
design) easier to set up than the real (production) ones.

Cheers, Ilja
